Conservation of Biodiversity in Central Zagros Region
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Objective To conserve the biodiversity in the Central Zagros Landscape Conservation Zone
ANNUAL RATE OF CONVERSION OF NATURAL HABITATS TO OTHER LAND USES WITHIN PMAS NEW

comment.narrative: TO BE DETERMINED USING GIS LAND COVER MAPPING
ANNUAL RATE OF CONVERSION IS LESS THAN 50 HA YEAR PER PMA

The amount of illegal land occupation in NaghanBoldagi was about 495 as below 75 ha in Miankooh Ardal County about 17 ha and also 25 ha of the Dureh in Bozoft
The amount of illegal occupation of land in West Dena was 5275 ha As below 1165 ha of the land use change in Boyer Ahmad and 216 ha land degradation in Dena
The illegal change of the land use of the pastures to dry land farming of about 05 ha seizing the pasture land in the form of planting of about 10 ha 9 ha of which was for planting apple and 1 was for plowing the pasture

description.narrative:
ge of the Zone under a management regime addressing mainstreaming biodiversity conservation THIS INDICATOR IS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB UNDP APPROVALS
BIODIVERSITY RICH FOREST RANGELAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS ARE CONSERVED AND RESTORED IN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS ACCORDING TO SPECIFICATIONS AND AREAS MAPPED IN MANAGEMENT PLANS NEW

comment.narrative: BASELINE SURVEYS OF HABITATS IN PMA CONSERVATION RESTORATION AREAS TO BE CONDUCTED

HABITAT CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS TOTALING AT LEAST 10000 HA IN EACH PMA ESTABLISHED AND FUNCTIONING SUPPORTED BY FINANCING PARTICIPATORY MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING MECHANISMS BY END OF 2016 NEW

The total area of Central Zagros Mountains CZM under study was extended after revision from 2500000 ha to 3100000 ha and 10 catchment management areas CMAs were designated to be managed Longterm and macro scale and the scalingup of the long term CZM management system started in 2 phases First in 2015 4 PMAs ie 393465 ha were extended to 4 CMAs with the total area of 1629000 ha At the second phase the remaining 6 CMAs not included in the former PMAs will be considered as a part of scaling up in 2016

description.narrative:
Population of selected key flagship species Persian squirrel and bear THIS INDICATOR IS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB UNDP APPROVALS
POPULATION OF SELECTED FLAGSHIP SPECIES FAUNA AND FLORA IN BD HOTSPOTS ACROSS THE ZONE
CHANGE IN STATUS OF INDICATOR SPECIES IN PMA CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS RELATED TO THE FOLLOWING ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS
a RANGELAND DEGRADATION SELECTED FLORA AND BUTTERFLY SPECIES SENSITIVE TO OVERGRAZING
b FOREST DEGRADATION AND LOSS DENSITY OF REGENERATING SEEDLINGS OF DOMINANT TREE SPECIES EG PERSIAN OAK
c RIVERINE HABITAT DEGRADATION EURASIAN OTTER
d HUNTING PRESSURE CHUKAR PARTRIDGE
NEW INDICATOR

comment.narrative: TO BE DETERMINED THROUGH BASELINE SURVEYS IN SAMPLING AREAS
STABLE OR INCREASING POPULATION TRENDS IN SAMPLING AREAS BY THE END OF 2016 NEW

A total of 94060 ha of forest and rangelands of the CZM has been occupied fired degreased and charcoal made during this period of PIR a twofold reduction in comparison with the 2014 PIR
A total of 4300 ha of Oak forest inside CZM is rehabilitated by FRWO to recover the forest habitats which have been affected by Oak Die Back disease
Illegal hunting of birds is reported 10 numbers also DoE reported the total number of watched choker partridge population 121 NaghanBoldagi
The population of Wild Goat is 4483 which has been raised for four times and the total number of chukar partridge population is 276 West Dena
Rehabilitation 10 Kms of Eurasian otter Habitat along Marbor River Dena Vanak
The population of Wild goat in Margoon is 9 Kor Kamfirouz

description.narrative: TRENDS IN AVERAGE SEDIMENT LOADS TOTAL SUSPENDED SOLIDS CARRIED BY MAJOR RIVERS ACROSS THE ZONE NEW

comment.narrative: TO BE DETERMINED FROM AVAILABLE DATA
STABLE OR DECREASING TRENDS IN TSS BY END 2016

The average of TSS for the main rivers of ChB Province are Sabzkooh 115 MgL which it shows highly promotion in compare with 2013 Sangan 083 MgL Koohrang 231 MgL Samsami 251 MgL Dinaran 249 MgL Pirooz 166 MgL
The average of moved sediment load in Boshar River increased for onesecond in compare with 2013

description.narrative:
Outcome 1
A national institutional and policy framework that is fully supportive of mainstreaming biodiversity into development in central Zagros mountains

Approved Strategy for development incorporating biodiversity THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDPAPPROVALS
NATIONALSUBNATIONAL PROGRAMME BD CONSERVATION IN ZAGROS MOUNTAINOUS LANDSCAPES APPROVED BY NATIONAL LEGISLATIVE ENTITIES AND OPERATIONAL INCLUDING REQUIRED BUDGET AND MONITORING FRAMEWORKS NEW

comment.narrative: NO SUCH NATIONAL MECHANISM EXISTS
END OF 2015 START OF 2016
CSD program finalized and submitted to IR Cabinet High council of Environment and MPO for approval designation and to be funded in the 6th five years National development plan

description.narrative:
Central level and provincial level mechanisms for intersectoral planning and coordination for conservation of MEMLs THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
A MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR CENTRAL ZAGROS MOUNTAINS IS FORMALLY ESTABLISHED AND LEGALLY DESIGNATED AS AN INTEGRATED MULTISECTOR RESOURCE INCLUDING SCALE UP STRATEGY NATIONAL POLICIES AND LAWS FRAMEWORKNEW

comment.narrative: NO FORMAL PROPOSAL EXISTS
End of 2015

Design CZM Management System and finalize scale up strategy for the long term and large scale CMAs and submit the proposal to Cabinet and PPDCs in four provinces to designate CMAs and establish the CZM management system and also process budget allocation to national and provincial CZM Executive Secretariats through 6th five years National Development Plan

description.narrative:
Conservation of Zagros biodiversity mentioned in at least 2 sectors Agriculture and Natural Resources in 5th Five Year Plan with clear objectives THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
A PERMANENT GOVERNING BODY NATIONAL AND PROVINCIAL FOR THE CZM REGION SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT MANAGEMENT IS FORMALLY DESIGNATED AND ESTABLISHED NEW

comment.narrative: NO PERMANENT OFFICE OR AGENCY IS DESIGNATED
END OF 2015 START OF 2016

The CZM governing body management system in national provincial and CMA levels is designed as a part of existing Irans governing system by some modifications and adaptations and work is under way to have this completely adopted with CSD Programme by the end of 2015

description.narrative:
Number of MoUs signed and started implementing between DoE and Ministries of Agriculture and Energy Cultural Heritage and Tourism Organization and Tribal Affairs Organisation THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BY MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
PROPOSALS FOR POLICY IMPROVEMENTS SUPPORTING MAINSTREAMING OF BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION INTO DEVELOPMENT OF THE ZAGROS MOUNTAINS DRAFTED AND SUBMITTED TO NATIONAL LEGISLATIVE ENTITIES FOR CONSIDERATION NEW

comment.narrative: PROPOSAL FOR ASSESSMENT OF EXISTING LEGAL POLICY FRAMEWORK DRAFTED
END OF 2015 START OF 2016

Conservation and Sustainable Development Programme C SD of Central Zagros Mountains CZM was developed and finalized based on the received feedbacks from the stakeholders at three levels National Provincial Local This document was approved by Project Boards

description.narrative: Outcome 2 Sustainable use and conservation of biodiversity integrated into economic and sectoral programmes and government practices at the conservation zone level
EXISTENCE OF FORMALLY ESTABLISHED AND OPERATIONAL INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY RESOURCES MANAGEMENT MECHANISMS FOR FOUR PROVINCES IN THE CENTRAL ZAGROS NEW

comment.narrative: PPDCS MANDATED TO COORDINATE ECONOMIC PLANNING BUT INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IS NOT FUNCTIONING IN REALITY
BY END 2015

Preparatory bilateral and consultancy meetings for establishment of CZM management committees and secretariats are as bellow
o Head of DoE as a secretary of High Council of Environment and chair of CZM National Committee for Sustainable Development CZM National Management Committee
o Provincial GGs as a chair of CZM provincial management committees
o Planning and Budgeting Deputy of GGs as a head of CZM provincial secretariat
o County Governors of first priority CMAs as a chair of CMA Management Committees
o The national provincial and local authorities as a member of CZM management committees in different levels
As a results of above meetings could be
o Approval for CZM CSD Programme by Project Board
o Initiate the establishment of CZM Provincial Executive Secretariats by GGs of four provinces
o Initiate up scaling the four PMAs LPCs to the first priority four CMAs Management Committees including Kor VanakKhersan Dena and Bazoft CMAs

description.narrative: FUNCTIONAL MANAGEMENT INFORMATION SYSTEM AND TOOLS IN PLACE IN FOUR PROVINCES SUPPORTING ZM REGION PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT NEW

comment.narrative: NO ORGANISED INFORMATION SYSTEM FOR CZM
BY END 2015

Conduct study on ecological capacity assessment of CZM and CMAs and data collection and organization through the single designed CZM Information Management System and negotiate with Provincial DoEs to upload the system and wildly make it available for all stakeholders and plan to build the capacity for CZM management committees and secretariat to use update and support the Information System

description.narrative:
increase in awareness and understanding on the importance of Zagros biodiversity among provincial level planners and policy makers THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
INFORMATION AND MANAGEMENT TOOLS ARE IN USE ASSISTING EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT NATURAL RESOURCE PLANNING AND CONSERVATION ACROSS THE CZM REGION NEW

comment.narrative: DATA COLLECTION ANALYSIS AND PLANNING CARRIED OUT SEPARATELY BY EACH RESOURCE SECTOR
RESOURCE CONSERVATION INFORMATION SYSTEM IN USE ACROSS CZM IN 2015

CZM Management Toolkit including Sustainable Resource Use Guidelines CZM Ecological Land Use Plan and Monitoring Plan and System is drafted and incorporated and disseminated through CZM Management Information System and CZM Resource Centers In parallel the Capacity Development Plan for CZM Management System drafted and is under implementation to empower CZM stakeholders for integrated and sustainable use and management of all resources

description.narrative:
No of provinces currently under project adopt measures approaches and practices developed under this project THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
MANAGEMENT OF ALL NATURAL RESOURCES AND SITES ACROSS THE CENTRAL ZAGROS MOUNTAINS REGION ARE INCORPORATED WITHIN THE CZM NEW

comment.narrative: NO CZM MANAGEMENT SYSTEM DEFINED
START OF FULLSCALE CZM CA BR IN 2015

Design 10 CMAs within CZM as an ecological and integrated management units and process development the guide for integrated and comanagement of CMAs including draft CMAs maps and profiles
The piloting of development PMAs annual WP is completed and reported under outcome 3 and scaling up of development of the annual integrated work plan for the first priority CMAs is under implementation

description.narrative:
Reduction in littering of major touristic spots of the region eg Margoon and Beheshte Gomshodeh as a proxy indicator of more BD conscious tourism THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
INFORMATION AND ADVICE ON A RANGE OF ECOLOGICALLYSUSTAINABLE RESOURCE ENTERPRISES AND LIVELIHOODS OPTIONS IN THE CZM ARE WIDELY AVAILABLE TO LOCAL AND PROVINCIAL STAKEHOLDERS NEW

comment.narrative: NO SYSTEMATIC DEVELOPMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION ON SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOOD OPTIONS
LIVELIHOODS INFORMATION IN USE ACROSS CZM IN 2015

Information materials and catalogue for sustainable resource enterprises and livelihoods within CZM is developed through survey and analysis of livelihood options in 120 villages of CZM and wildly introduced and disseminated through CZM Information Management System
The concept papers for green development and sustainable resource use initiatives including green agriculture fisheries water and waste rangeland forest tourism landscape Village Livelihood and sustainable life of nomads have been drafted and the participatory development of green projects is initiated in each province
The piloting of B E Grant Scheme is completed and the proposal for the long term and large scale is drafted and submitted to PPDCs for approval funding and implementation

description.narrative:
reduction of unsustainable harvesting of non wood forests products such as medicinal herbs and aromatic plants of nomad families adopt improved grazing and livelihood practices THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
CATALOGUE OF EVALUATED RESOURCE MATERIALS FOR 50 INCOME GENERATION AND LIVELIHOOD OPTIONS AVAILABLE FOR RURAL AND NOMAD COMMUNITIES IN CENTRAL ZAGROSNEW

comment.narrative: NO SYSTEMATIC APPROACH TO SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS PLANNING OR DEVELOPMENT

FIRST VERSION OF CATALOGUE IN 2014
50 nomad families in the pilot areas adopt alternativegreen enterprises by the end of the project

Information materials and catalog for sustainable resource enterprises and livelihoods within CZM is developed through survey and analysis of livelihood options in 120 villages of CZM and introduced and disseminated through CZM Information Management System

description.narrative: SUPPORTIVE MECHANISMS FOR BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION AND INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN THE CENTRAL ZAGROS THE SECTOR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES WITH SUSTAINABILITY GUIDELINES FORESTRY WATER GRAZING AQUACULTURE TOURISM ETC BE GRANT SCHEME AND CZ RCS ARE INSTITUTIONALIZED ADEQUATELY RESOURCED AND FULLY OPERATIONAL NEW

comment.narrative: NO SECTOR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES IN PLACE
BY END 2015

Develop and publish nine sustainability resource use guidelines including Water Resource Agriculture Aquaculture Forest Rangeland Tourism Solid Waste and Effluent Management and EIA
The results of piloting B E Grant Scheme is approval and allocating budget to four submitted proposals two ecotourism one rangeland conservation and one mushroom planting project by LPCs and implementation the above projects by NGOs and CBOs in Dena Vanak and Naghan PMAs also approval of two submitted proposal by LPC in West Dena
Establish and activate the Zagros Mountains Resource Centers ZMRCs in the 4 provinces with collaboration of local NGOs and also support the RCs links in the DoEs portals of Fars Isfahan Kohgiloye va Boyerahamad and Chaharmahalo Bakhtiari

description.narrative: Outcome 3 Successful sustainable financially replicable models of village designed and driven approaches to increasing income generation and conserving biodiversity in biodiversity rich areas coordination monitoring advocacy and adaptive management

increase in household income at pilot village THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBGEFRO APPROVALS
PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTIONS IMPLEMENTED AND EVALUATED IN EACH PILOT MA STRATEGIC PILOT LIVELIHOOD INITIATIVES IMPLEMENTED AND EVALUATED IN EACH PILOT MA NEW

comment.narrative: NO SYSTEMATIC MONITORING AND EVALUATION
END OF 2014 START OF 2015

Implementation seven conservation and sustainable livelihood projects namely
o Wild and bird watching in West Dena including forming the Local Tour Guide CBO 15 villagers from 3 villages provide equipment and establish one ecolodge and entertain one tour within the village and encourage the hunters to be more familiar with the wildlife
o Develop sustainable livelihood action plan in NaqanBuldaji and build the capacity of 45 rural female and 56 rural male from four villages for development ecological livelihood namely planting medical herbs carpet mushroom beekeeping compost sewing local clothes
o sustainable ecotourism in KorKamfirouz including build capacity for 20 rural youth as CBO in Mengan Village equip and establish three ecolodge wild watching cottages and handicraft shop and also entertain four groups of visitors
o Rural Handicrafts development in NaqanBuldaji including capacity development for the 20 female villagers and forming the Sholiz CBO conduct local provincial and national handicraft exhibitions marketing and provide income for female villagers and involve them in rehabilitation of Oak forest
o Rehabilitation and conservation of medical herbs in Dena Vanakincluding planting of 12000 seeds of Dracocephalum kotschyi Boiss Thymus daenenss and build the capacity for 10 nomads and support them in marketing
o 2nd phase of IPCM Integrated Participatory Crop Management in KorKamfirouz including establish six CBO 25 villagers in each group through infrastructures in 6 core villages The result has been disseminated to all CZM provinces by the MOJA to be included in their annual program
o Conduct the study for Analyzing the effect of environmental factors on the implementation of the fungi in the mass of Oak Forest die back in Iran in West Dena by the cooperation of FRWO Based on the first report Yasuj University came to this idea that the bacteria as the secondary factor in Oak Die Back not a Fungi

description.narrative:
Local participation in conservation activities increased Proxy indicator number of village conservation groups formed and started to take responsibility to protect forests adjacent to their village THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PBUNDP APPROVALS
LEVEL OF SUPPORT FOR BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION INCREASES WITHIN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS AS INDICATED BY THE NUMBER OF LOCAL CONSERVATION GROUPS FORMED AND ACTIVELY PARTICIPATING IN CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES NEW

comment.narrative: NO LOCAL CONSERVATION GROUPS
AT LEAST 8 LOCAL CONSERVATION GROUPS BY END 2016

Ten local conservation groups established as follows
o The female CBO Sholiz with 20 members in Gelsefid Village This CBO has 4 working groups to produce and sold the handicrafts also they were engage in rehabilitating the 18 ha of Oak forest
o Qalbe Dena Denas Heart as a local eco tour guide CBO with 15 active villagers from three villages namely Khoongah Ab Sepah and Dashte Raz
o Forming 6 Volunteer IPCM CBOs from 3 villages of kor namely Bakian Sarbast and Hosseinabad and 3 villages in Kamfirouz namely Abbasabad Chogha and Mansoorabad each CBO has 25 members and the total is 150 villagers

independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Enhanced carbon sequestration in soil and vegetation across landscape in project demonstration sites

Wind erosion control in Sistan 50 ha 20 ha new in this reporting period Flood control and Soil erosion control 12500 ha 5000 ha in Kermanshah and 6000 ha in Hableerud are new in this reporting period sustainable agriculture 40 ha 33 ha in Kermanshah and 7 ha in Yazd are new in this reporting period cultivation resistance species Medical plant cultivation wild almond cultivation pistachio and saffron cultivation to use less water 1124 ha 1024ha new in this reporting period Totally 2208 persons 361 new persons men and women involved in the project management

description.narrative: Increase in bestpractice organic and traditionallocal innovations in land and water management biodiversity conservation and climate change resilience

comment.narrative: Current use measured in Y1
8 innovations at demonstration sites

8 innovations at demonstration sites were established one new in this reporting period that is producing 4 solar driers to demonstrate in each pilot sites
Traditionally extra vegetable and fruits were dried to be kept for a longer course of time The system they used to it is not hygienic market acceptable and healthy Solar food dehydrator is a simple set which led the farmer to dry their materials in dust and insect free environment Fruits and vegetable are dried in shade to keep their essential oils and vitamins It help rural to take benefit of sun and there is no need of other sources such as fuel which is getting more expensive these days This set is suitable for a gardener who has one or more fruit garden Result of primarily tests is satisfactory and local people are interested to make more sets for their own

a 73000 tons of carbon valuing USD416000 US57 per ton through sequestration of 60000 tons and emission reduction of 13000 tons of carbon

c 4 sub projects at demonstration sites for rehabilitation of irrigation and rain fed areas of 4000 hectares rehabilitated and delivering 30 increased water use efficiency
d 4 sub projects at demonstration site for improving resilience to climate change forest and rangelands cover in project area increased by 10

a the project has contributed to climate change mitigation through sequestrating 37076 tons of carbon
b4 PES mechanisms put in place Conservation of biodiversity project rangeland management to conserve plant diversity in Behabad site in Yazd Province Payment for carbon sequestration implementation of regulating line planting trees and water management in Razin site in Kermanshah Province Payment for countering land degradation planting of tamarisk in degraded agricultural lands in order to counter the encroachment of moving sand in Hamoun site in Sistan and Baluchestan Province Payment for increasing water use efficiency repair and restoration of qanat in Amidabad village in Semnan Province
c6 projects on rehabilitation of irrigation and rain fed were done Rehabilitation of around 2700 meters of Qanat in Amid Abad hableerud basin improving water irrigation efficiency through rehabilitation of 1600 meters irrigation channels in Asad Abad 700 ha watershed management in Razin of Kermanshah rehabilitation of 1340 meters of Qanat in KarimabadYazd Increase water efficiency of agricultural through water transfer pipes in Kamkoyeh 1340 meters and 1000 meters in Karimabad constructing a forestry park 100 ha based on rain harvesting
d 5 rangeland management cases 2 new in this reporting period in Kermanshah 170 ha Yazd 130 ha and Hablerud 3300 ha were done totaly

description.narrative: IWRM and WUE strategies in place with institutional ownership secured and best approaches mainstreamed into national and regional planning frameworks by end of project

comment.narrative:
Weak policies communication coordination resulting in fragile or nonexistent IWRM approaches in place
Water Use Efficiency is poorly understood and often not considered in water management decisions

IWRM and Water Use Efficiency Strategies in place Technical management participatory and advocacy lessons from demonstration sites developed into presentation packages with best practices mainstreamed into national and regional approaches by end of project

Two Water Use Efficiency Strategies were prepared by participation of local communities water agency Jahade agriculture natural resource organization and project technical experts in Tehran province Base on these strategies an organization established that named Ab Baran that those farmers who are responsible for water management are its members This organization is responsible for implementing the strategies

title.narrative: Building a Multiple-Use Forest Management Framework to Conserve Biodiversity in the Caspian Hyrcanian Forest Landscape

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

Caspian Forests Conservation o
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration

To put in place a collaborative governance system and knowhow for managing a mosaic of land uses in the Caspian Hyrcanian forest that provides habitat integrity and helps maintain landscape level ecosystem functions and resilience
Area of biodiversity setasides created governed by clear specific management guidelines

comment.narrative: Some areas 10 are under biodiversity setasides but without any systematic management regime for biodiversity conservation
At least 100000 ha of new biodiversity set asides under FRWO management defined with management guidelines

FRWO is managing Forest Reserves and Forest Parks in which rare plant species are conserved and protected The idea of BD Setasides puts forward a holistic mechanism through which both Fauna and Flora are under management regimes by FRWO Aiming at developing management regimes for better management of biodiversity in the whole Caspian Hyrcanina Area Special Areas for Biodiversity SABs will be established in consultation with FRWO technical divisions and DoE as the main relevant stakeholder SABs will be managed based on modern Biosphere Reserve model to ensure conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity Fauna and Flora A concept note has been developed on designing and management of SABs which was consulted in an inclusive biodiversity workshop Potential SABs have been initially mapped by relevant stakeholders and draft codes of practice prepared in a participatory manner Potential sites will be further studied and 100000 ha of area will be assigned and designated as SABs by Forest High Council by mid2016 Further steps will be taken to register SABs as biosphere reserves after the approval of the Forest HighCouncil

description.narrative: Extent and quality of forest cover IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative:
Incidents of illicit felling involving creaming of commercially important species
Clearance of forest areas for agriculture leading to 05 loss of forests
No net loss of forest cover and improved quality with reduced loss of high grade species

Forest degradation is not only due to deforestation but also is mainly because of depletion of the forest quality There is no single indicator based on which one can assess the quality of forest Therefore further to conducting forest cover assessment through remote sensing methods the project arranged a comprehensive forest condition assessment through which 16 different forest parameters were measured The field study is finished and report writing is in final stages Forest quality parameters have been measured in pilot landscapes in the FRWO network of permanent monitoring plots with an area of 1000 square meters Forest cover and biodiversity parameters were also measured in the same network to be attributable The study will be repeated at the end of the project implementation for comparing results

description.narrative: Improvement in Total Capacity Development Scorecard Annex V

comment.narrative:
26 at the midterm evaluatiuon course
42 at the final evaluation course

CD Scorecards were updated through consultation with the project team and stakeholders through which a cumulative score of 10 was calculated again A Capacity Development Plan was drafted by the project which will be further improved though consultation with stakeholders and the project team specially at the local level has been the main development change during the reporting period Furthermore holding consultative Integrated Management Plan sessions in pilot landscapes in which representatives of all stakeholder groups including local communities is considered as a very effective capacity development tool for engagement of multiple stakeholders in planning Impacts of these capacity development practices will be measured in the midterm of the project implementation

description.narrative: Landscape area in the Caspian Hyrcanian forests where forestry and other production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: 0 ha
Policy and regulatory frameworks for managing multiple use forest landscapes across 800000 ha of forests

Policy and regulatory frameworks have been reviewed through project financial resources to explore gaps for integration and mainstreaming of participatory multipurpose forestry and biodiversity conservation in sectoral policies laws and regulations as well as institutional mechanisms such as monitoring and law enforcement systems The study is at the final stages and its expected to suggest amendments to policies laws and regulations and institutional mechanisms The study suggests that there are almost no barrier in policies laws and regulatory frameworks to prevent FRWO and other government agencies to apply participatory forest management The study is also encouraging the parliament to approve the national Comprehensive Natural Resources Law which is awaiting the final steps in there A number of suggestions will come out of the study to enrich the regulatory framework of forest management These suggestions will go to the Forest High Council for further action and taking into practice In addition the project contributed to development of relevant articles of the 6th National Development Plan and incorporated participatory multipurpose forestry in its draft version as a mandate for all government sectors during 201620

description.narrative: STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative: SPECIES AND BASELINE TO BE SET IN 2014
NO DECLINE IN STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES BY END OF PROJECT

No change is expected to be measured in this stage Based on discussions with the biodiversity consultants as well as project CTA and approval of project board changes of biodiversity status and trends could not be measured in short periods Hence biodiversity survey will be repeated at the end of the project to assess the changes against the baseline Status of mammals is under study in all four pilot landscapes The study is focused on a few number of flagship species like Red Deer Roe Deer Persian Leopard Wolf Wild Boar and Brown Bear Mammals study is also addressing humanwildlife conflicts which is a very important cause for killing of animals and will be concluded with a plan for conflict resolution in each of the pilot landscapes

description.narrative: An enabling policy and regulatory framework for multiple use forest management is developed
Extent of integration of ecosystem values into production sector strategies and plans

comment.narrative: Ecosystem goods and services are utilised by production sectors however their true ecological value is not understood or incorporated into the economics of key production sectors
Systematic analysis of values of forests and externalities of deforestation and forest degradation incorporated into sector decisions and finance options identified to offset opportunity costs

Ecosystem services in pilot landscapes have been mapped by application of a novel tool called InVest software The software is used for the first time ever in the country which offers visual understanding of ecosystem services in two scenarios of present and future The future scenario can be used as a supporting tool for decision making in pilot landscapes economic values of ecosystem services are being calculated which will be followed by designing of financial options under Payment for Ecosystem Services PES The whole set of study is being conducted by a team of national consultants and supervision of international consultant The study will be finalized by Q2 2016 The study has been involving relevant stakeholders mainly Government entities in training and consultation sessions and helped a lot in raising the awareness an building capacities on ecosystem services and their economic values

description.narrative: INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING sustainable land use plan defines a clear direction for the Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and supports mainstreaming biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Land use plans exist at the basincatchment levels under FRWO management and similar plans exist for DoE management of PAs However a coordinated plan for production sectors does not exist

INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING Sustainable land use plan for Caspian Hyrcanian forest that a define biodiversity rich areas to be gazetted as new PAs and b lay out appropriate landuses and management practices to be prescribed in the adjacent production landscape

To ensure intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and adoption of a harmonized approach between all three Casian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape a so called Hyrcanian Forest Green Development Strategy is under preparation The first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015 The Strategy will include a zoning plan for the whole Caspian area which will locate the main landuse categories across the whole region The Zoning Plan is also under preparation

description.narrative: INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED National policy and regulatory framework is adjusted to meet BD mainstreaming requirements and is updated within operational procedures

comment.narrative: FRWO and other FMPs are not coordinated and lack inclusion of biodiversity conservation practices

INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED AT HYRCANIAN FOREST AND PILOT LANDSCAPE LEVELS
1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning issued

Local Coordination Committees LCCs have been regularly meeting on a quarterly basis as the main intersectoral coordination mechanism at the local level LCCs have been heavily involved in development of Integrated Management Plans IMPs which ensures functioning of the mechanism Regional Coordination Committee RCC was established as the main driver for intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests The latter makes sure a harmonized approach between all three Caspian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape through development and implementation of the so called Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy The Strategy is under preparation after the first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015

description.narrative: Operational guidelines are being utilised to manage multiple land uses in forest landscapes including improved forestry small holder agriculture and livestock practices

comment.narrative: Forestry tourism and agriculture sectors lack a coordinated approach to management
At least 3 improved operational guidelines for i improved forestry ii sustainable small holder agriculture iii improved livestock practices and iv sustainable tourism

As the sectoral guidelines should encompass best practices and lessons learned preparation of these guidelines will be subject to slight postponement Development of guidelines starts in the second half of 2015 ToR for national coordinating consultant is drafted ad under finalization

description.narrative: Community based integrated forest management piloted
Number of activities included in the alternative livelihood development strategy that are implemented and percentage increase in income of community groups

comment.narrative:
0
Income baseline of community groups will be established during the first year

At least 4 different types of alternative livelihood activities such as beekeeping NTFP enterprise rural handicrafts aquaculture dairy product marketing etc to be further selected from the PPG shortlist during IW
At least 1520 increase in income of targeted community groups

The alternative Livelihood Strategy is still under preparation in a consultative manner and based on indepth and comprehensive data and knowledge that the project gained in all four pilot landscapes Feasibility of low impact ecotourism is being assessed in all four pilots and the study is expected to come to an end in 3 months However alternative livelihood options is being taken in two of the pilot landscapes 6 women groups in Chehelchai are progressively making handicrafts and selling them under their name and brand Handicrafts are made from local materials and have roots in their culture Women groups have been able to generate significant amount of income as much as 5000 during the reporting period In project pilot landscape in Guilan Province two youth groups was established which are taking alternative options for income generation One group is developing its skills to do ecotourism activities The group has been able to take two groups of local tourists to the vicinity forest The other group tried to establish a nursery to produce seedlings of forest species Because of some legal challenges they have changed the idea and are trying to grow mushrooms as another alternative

description.narrative: Number of community based forest management plans developed AGREED BY COMMUNITY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES and implemented

comment.narrative: 2 COMMUNITY BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS COVERING 30000HA

FRWO has been practicing traditional forestry activities for several decades There are significant resistances against application of Community Forestry CF in technical and managerial disciplines of FRWO On the other hand local communities lack enough capacities to engage in CF planning and implementation The project has organized an introductory session on CF followed by a comprehensive training on this topic aiming at building capacities in FRWO for CF and reducing resistances Local communities have been aso exposed to the idea during the reporting period Its expected that development of CF plans will start towards the end of 2015 in limited areas first n Chehelchai and Sehezar pilots and then in Baliran In Fariroud Narvan cooperative is doing CF which needs adjustments to bring inclusiveness and equity There seem to be willingness to apply these amendments The project will start facilitation for these adjustments towards the end 2015

description.narrative: Number of people shifting to alternative livelihood options that reduce pressure on biodiversity

comment.narrative: Baseline to be collected in Year 1
TARGET TO BE DEFINED IN 2014 AFTER DESIGN OF ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS PLAN

In total 8 groups of local communities 6 women groups and 2 youth groups started adoption of alternative livelihoods to reduce the pressure over forest landscapes Alternative Livelihood Strategy is under preparation and will be finalized in Q3 2015

description.narrative: PUBLIC AWARENESS OF FOREST GOODS AND SERVICES VALUES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

comment.narrative: TBD 2014
PUBLIC AWARENESS INCREASES 20 OVERALL AND 50 IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

The awareness baseline is set for all four pilot landscapes vicinity downtowns and provincial capital cities The shift in the level of awareness will be measured at the end of the project implementation again compared to the baseline However the project has developed Communication and Awareness Raising Plan which is under implementation The project has launched a bilingual website 5 issues of newsletter 1 series 4 volumes of brochures on pilot landscapes and a number of other awareness raising materials

description.narrative: The rate of forest clearance under CFM as compared against nonCFM areas

comment.narrative: Baseline to be measured for both CFM and nonCFM in 2014
Forest degradation due to agriculture illegal cutting and livestock grazing in community pilots decreased by at least 50 in total pilot area and less than nonCFM area
The baseline for forest clearance is under preparation through socioeconomic and forest condition assessment studies Both studies will be finalized by Q3 2015

CD Scorecards were updated through consultation with the project team and stakeholders through which a cumulative score of 10 was calculated again A Capacity Development Plan was drafted by the project which needs further improvements though consultation with stakeholders and the project team specially at the local level has been the main development change during the reporting period Furthermore holding consultative IMP sessions in pilot landscapes in which representatives of all stakeholder groups including local communities is considered as a very effective capacity development tool for engagement of multiple stakeholders in planning Impacts of these capacity development practices will be measured in the midterm of the project implementation

description.narrative: Number of FRWO and other sector staff trained and able to apply multipleuse forest management approaches

comment.narrative:
FRWO 100
Agriculture 50
Mining 20
Tourism 50
Animal Husbandry 50

At least 300 people from different line sectors forestry agriculture biodiversity conservation tourism water ministry of interior academia NGOs and local community representatives attended all these training and consultative sessions during the reporting period

description.narrative: Number of training materials and best practices prepared and incorporated into FRWO management planning and induction courses

comment.narrative: At least 3

Project training plan is recently drafted 2 comprehensive trainings on social forestry and ecosystem services values have been offered during the reporting period Consultation sessions to develop IMPs SABs proposal and Social Forestry Roadmap have been conducted through which training and capacity building modules have been offered At least 300 people from different line sectors and local community representatives attended all these training and consultative sessions during the reporting period MoU is under finalization to be signed between the project and Training and Public Participation Bureau of FRWO for joint collaboration and inclusion of relevant trainings in the official induction and inservice training programmes of FRWO

description.narrative: Replication strategy FOR SUSTAINABLE LAND USE PLAN IN PILOT LANDSCAPES that provide a clear intellectual means to expand the work of the project into the wider Caspian Hyrcanian forest landscape

comment.narrative: NA
Replication plan FOR PILOT landscapes initiated with secured resources from central and provincial government by the end of the project
Development of the replication plan will start in 2017 and its implementation will start in 2018

description.narrative: Use of a functional and effective monitoring mechanism for community based illicit felling and land clearing

comment.narrative: Community based forests require support for monitoring
Effective monitoring systems in place to control harvesting forest resources

The study to review existing monitoring and enforcement mechanisms initiated and will be finalized in Q3 2015 The final conclusion of the study will be a number of proposals and a stepwise roadmap to adjust and amend existing mechanisms and make them more effective and aligned with multipurpose forest management requirements

description.narrative: Design and Development of a National Social Protection and Empowerment Model towards Capability Poverty Reduction, Employment Generation, and Inclusive Growth Outcomes
Support development of national empowerment model for social protection.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

This project will extend the institutional strengthening support for two additional years from January 2015 to December 2016 for the national Ozone Layer Protection Unit, Department of Environment of the Government of Islamic Republic of Iran.

This project will extend the institutional strengthening support for two additional years from April 2015 to March 2017 for the national Ozone Layer Protection Unit, Department of Environment of the Government of Islamic Republic of Iran.
Institutional Strengthening renewal for Phase XI
